The patient is a 67-year-old female with a history of atrial fibrillation, COPD/asthma, osteoporosis, glaucoma, and hyperlipidemia. She presented to the ICU after undergoing a pulmonary vein isolation procedure. The patient developed cardiac tamponade during the procedure and had a pericardiocentesis performed, with approximately 250cc of fluid drained. Hypotension developed, and the patient was supported with phenylephrine. Her hematocrit dropped from 45% to 34.7%. The patient was extubated, sedation and phenylephrine were weaned, and the drainage has been sparse since the morning. 

The patient's left common femoral artery (CFA) pseudoaneurysm was evaluated by vascular surgery and is currently stable. A repeat ultrasound is recommended in four weeks, and if the pseudoaneurysm increases from 1.2 to >2 cm, the patient may need a thrombin injection.

The patient's rhythm has been challenging to control, with evidence of atypical atrial flutter overnight. She is beginning to respond to amiodarone load. Tele monitoring will be continued, and amiodarone 400mg po qd for two weeks, along with IV amio load today, will be continued. Coumadin will be restarted today, and the patient will be NPO at midnight for possible cardioversion tomorrow.
